text: These are the proverbs of Solomon, David’s son, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their purpose is to teach people wisdom and discipline,
    to help them understand the insights of the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their purpose is to teach people to live disciplined and successful lives,
    to help them do what is right, just, and fair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These proverbs will give insight to the simple,
    knowledge and discernment to the young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the wise listen to these proverbs and become even wiser.
    Let those with understanding receive guidance
speaker: Narrator

text:
by exploring the meaning in these proverbs and parables,
    the words of the wise and their riddles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear of the Lord is the foundation of true knowledge,
    but fools despise wisdom and discipline.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, listen when your father corrects you.
    Don’t neglect your mother’s instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What you learn from them will crown you with grace
    and be a chain of honor around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if sinners entice you,
    turn your back on them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They may say, “Come and join us.
    Let’s hide and kill someone!
    Just for fun, let’s ambush the innocent!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s swallow them alive, like the grave;
    let’s swallow them whole, like those who go down to the pit of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Think of the great things we’ll get!
    We’ll fill our houses with all the stuff we take.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, throw in your lot with us;
    we’ll all share the loot.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, don’t go along with them!
    Stay far away from their paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They rush to commit evil deeds.
    They hurry to commit murder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a bird sees a trap being set,
    it knows to stay away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But these people set an ambush for themselves;
    they are trying to get themselves killed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such is the fate of all who are greedy for money;
    it robs them of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom shouts in the streets.
    She cries out in the public square.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She calls to the crowds along the main street,
    to those gathered in front of the city gate:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long, you simpletons,
    will you insist on being simpleminded?
How long will you mockers relish your mocking?
    How long will you fools hate knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come and listen to my counsel.
I’ll share my heart with you
    and make you wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I called you so often, but you wouldn’t come.
    I reached out to you, but you paid no attention.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You ignored my advice
    and rejected the correction I offered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will laugh when you are in trouble!
    I will mock you when disaster overtakes you—
speaker: Narrator

text:
when calamity overtakes you like a storm,
    when disaster engulfs you like a cyclone,
    and anguish and distress overwhelm you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When they cry for help, I will not answer.
    Though they anxiously search for me, they will not find me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they hated knowledge
    and chose not to fear the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They rejected my advice
    and paid no attention when I corrected them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, they must eat the bitter fruit of living their own way,
    choking on their own schemes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For simpletons turn away from me—to death.
    Fools are destroyed by their own complacency.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But all who listen to me will live in peace,
    untroubled by fear of harm.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, listen to what I say,
    and treasure my commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tune your ears to wisdom,
    and concentrate on understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cry out for insight,
    and ask for understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Search for them as you would for silver;
    seek them like hidden treasures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will understand what it means to fear the Lord,
    and you will gain knowledge of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord grants wisdom!
    From his mouth come knowledge and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He grants a treasure of common sense to the honest.
    He is a shield to those who walk with integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He guards the paths of the just
    and protects those who are faithful to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will understand what is right, just, and fair,
    and you will find the right way to go.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wisdom will enter your heart,
    and knowledge will fill you with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise choices will watch over you.
    Understanding will keep you safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom will save you from evil people,
    from those whose words are twisted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These men turn from the right way
    to walk down dark paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They take pleasure in doing wrong,
    and they enjoy the twisted ways of evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their actions are crooked,
    and their ways are wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom will save you from the immoral woman,
    from the seductive words of the promiscuous woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has abandoned her husband
    and ignores the covenant she made before God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Entering her house leads to death;
    it is the road to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man who visits her is doomed.
    He will never reach the paths of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So follow the steps of the good,
    and stay on the paths of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For only the godly will live in the land,
    and those with integrity will remain in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the wicked will be removed from the land,
    and the treacherous will be uprooted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, never forget the things I have taught you.
    Store my commands in your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you do this, you will live many years,
    and your life will be satisfying.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never let loyalty and kindness leave you!
    Tie them around your neck as a reminder.
    Write them deep within your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will find favor with both God and people,
    and you will earn a good reputation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in the Lord with all your heart;
    do not depend on your own understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Seek his will in all you do,
    and he will show you which path to take.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t be impressed with your own wisdom.
    Instead, fear the Lord and turn away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will have healing for your body
    and strength for your bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honor the Lord with your wealth
    and with the best part of everything you produce.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he will fill your barns with grain,
    and your vats will overflow with good wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, don’t reject the Lord’s discipline,
    and don’t be upset when he corrects you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord corrects those he loves,
    just as a father corrects a child in whom he delights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joyful is the person who finds wisdom,
    the one who gains understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wisdom is more profitable than silver,
    and her wages are better than gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is more precious than rubies;
    nothing you desire can compare with her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She offers you long life in her right hand,
    and riches and honor in her left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She will guide you down delightful paths;
    all her ways are satisfying.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is a tree of life to those who embrace her;
    happy are those who hold her tightly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By wisdom the Lord founded the earth;
    by understanding he created the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his knowledge the deep fountains of the earth burst forth,
    and the dew settles beneath the night sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, don’t lose sight of common sense and discernment.
    Hang on to them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for they will refresh your soul.
    They are like jewels on a necklace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They keep you safe on your way,
    and your feet will not stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You can go to bed without fear;
    you will lie down and sleep soundly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You need not be afraid of sudden disaster
    or the destruction that comes upon the wicked,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the Lord is your security.
    He will keep your foot from being caught in a trap.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not withhold good from those who deserve it
    when it’s in your power to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you can help your neighbor now, don’t say,
    “Come back tomorrow, and then I’ll help you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t plot harm against your neighbor,
    for those who live nearby trust you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t pick a fight without reason,
    when no one has done you harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t envy violent people
    or copy their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such wicked people are detestable to the Lord,
    but he offers his friendship to the godly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord curses the house of the wicked,
    but he blesses the home of the upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord mocks the mockers
    but is gracious to the humble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise inherit honor,
    but fools are put to shame!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My children, listen when your father corrects you.
    Pay attention and learn good judgment,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for I am giving you good guidance.
    Don’t turn away from my instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I, too, was once my father’s son,
    tenderly loved as my mother’s only child.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My father taught me,
“Take my words to heart.
    Follow my commands, and you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get wisdom; develop good judgment.
    Don’t forget my words or turn away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t turn your back on wisdom, for she will protect you.
    Love her, and she will guard you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Getting wisdom is the wisest thing you can do!
    And whatever else you do, develop good judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you prize wisdom, she will make you great.
    Embrace her, and she will honor you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She will place a lovely wreath on your head;
    she will present you with a beautiful crown.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, listen to me and do as I say,
    and you will have a long, good life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will teach you wisdom’s ways
    and lead you in straight paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you walk, you won’t be held back;
    when you run, you won’t stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take hold of my instructions; don’t let them go.
    Guard them, for they are the key to life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t do as the wicked do,
    and don’t follow the path of evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t even think about it; don’t go that way.
    Turn away and keep moving.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For evil people can’t sleep until they’ve done their evil deed for the day.
    They can’t rest until they’ve caused someone to stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They eat the food of wickedness
    and drink the wine of violence!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the righteous is like the first gleam of dawn,
    which shines ever brighter until the full light of day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the way of the wicked is like total darkness.
    They have no idea what they are stumbling over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, pay attention to what I say.
    Listen carefully to my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t lose sight of them.
    Let them penetrate deep into your heart,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for they bring life to those who find them,
    and healing to their whole body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Guard your heart above all else,
    for it determines the course of your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Avoid all perverse talk;
    stay away from corrupt speech.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look straight ahead,
    and fix your eyes on what lies before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mark out a straight path for your feet;
    stay on the safe path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t get sidetracked;
    keep your feet from following evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, pay attention to my wisdom;
    listen carefully to my wise counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will show discernment,
    and your lips will express what you’ve learned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the lips of an immoral woman are as sweet as honey,
    and her mouth is smoother than oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But in the end she is as bitter as poison,
    as dangerous as a double-edged sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her feet go down to death;
    her steps lead straight to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For she cares nothing about the path to life.
    She staggers down a crooked trail and doesn’t realize it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now, my sons, listen to me.
    Never stray from what I am about to say:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stay away from her!
    Don’t go near the door of her house!
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you do, you will lose your honor
    and will lose to merciless people all you have achieved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strangers will consume your wealth,
    and someone else will enjoy the fruit of your labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the end you will groan in anguish
    when disease consumes your body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will say, “How I hated discipline!
    If only I had not ignored all the warnings!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, why didn’t I listen to my teachers?
    Why didn’t I pay attention to my instructors?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have come to the brink of utter ruin,
    and now I must face public disgrace.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Drink water from your own well—
    share your love only with your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why spill the water of your springs in the streets,
    having sex with just anyone?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You should reserve it for yourselves.
    Never share it with strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your wife be a fountain of blessing for you.
    Rejoice in the wife of your youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is a loving deer, a graceful doe.
    Let her breasts satisfy you always.
    May you always be captivated by her love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why be captivated, my son, by an immoral woman,
    or fondle the breasts of a promiscuous woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord sees clearly what a man does,
    examining every path he takes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An evil man is held captive by his own sins;
    they are ropes that catch and hold him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will die for lack of self-control;
    he will be lost because of his great foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if you have put up security for a friend’s debt
    or agreed to guarantee the debt of a stranger—
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you have trapped yourself by your agreement
    and are caught by what you said—
speaker: Narrator

text:
follow my advice and save yourself,
    for you have placed yourself at your friend’s mercy.
Now swallow your pride;
    go and beg to have your name erased.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t put it off; do it now!
    Don’t rest until you do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Save yourself like a gazelle escaping from a hunter,
    like a bird fleeing from a net.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take a lesson from the ants, you lazybones.
    Learn from their ways and become wise!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though they have no prince
    or governor or ruler to make them work,
speaker: Narrator

text:
they labor hard all summer,
    gathering food for the winter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you, lazybones, how long will you sleep?
    When will you wake up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little extra sleep, a little more slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to rest—
speaker: Narrator

text:
then poverty will pounce on you like a bandit;
    scarcity will attack you like an armed robber.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What are worthless and wicked people like?
    They are constant liars,
speaker: Narrator

text:
signaling their deceit with a wink of the eye,
    a nudge of the foot, or the wiggle of fingers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their perverted hearts plot evil,
    and they constantly stir up trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they will be destroyed suddenly,
    broken in an instant beyond all hope of healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are six things the Lord hates—
    no, seven things he detests:
speaker: Narrator

text:
haughty eyes,
    a lying tongue,
    hands that kill the innocent,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a heart that plots evil,
    feet that race to do wrong,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a false witness who pours out lies,
    a person who sows discord in a family.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My son, obey your father’s commands,
    and don’t neglect your mother’s instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep their words always in your heart.
    Tie them around your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you walk, their counsel will lead you.
    When you sleep, they will protect you.
    When you wake up, they will advise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For their command is a lamp
    and their instruction a light;
their corrective discipline
    is the way to life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will keep you from the immoral woman,
    from the smooth tongue of a promiscuous woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t lust for her beauty.
    Don’t let her coy glances seduce you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a prostitute will bring you to poverty,
    but sleeping with another man’s wife will cost you your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can a man scoop a flame into his lap
    and not have his clothes catch on fire?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can he walk on hot coals
    and not blister his feet?
speaker: Narrator

text:
So it is with the man who sleeps with another man’s wife.
    He who embraces her will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Excuses might be found for a thief
    who steals because he is starving.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if he is caught, he must pay back seven times what he stole,
    even if he has to sell everything in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the man who commits adultery is an utter fool,
    for he destroys himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will be wounded and disgraced.
    His shame will never be erased.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the woman’s jealous husband will be furious,
    and he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will accept no compensation,
    nor be satisfied with a payoff of any size.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Follow my advice, my son;
    always treasure my commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Obey my commands and live!
    Guard my instructions as you guard your own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tie them on your fingers as a reminder.
    Write them deep within your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Love wisdom like a sister;
    make insight a beloved member of your family.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them protect you from an affair with an immoral woman,
    from listening to the flattery of a promiscuous woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While I was at the window of my house,
    looking through the curtain,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I saw some naive young men,
    and one in particular who lacked common sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He was crossing the street near the house of an immoral woman,
    strolling down the path by her house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It was at twilight, in the evening,
    as deep darkness fell.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The woman approached him,
    seductively dressed and sly of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She was the brash, rebellious type,
    never content to stay at home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is often in the streets and markets,
    soliciting at every corner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She threw her arms around him and kissed him,
    and with a brazen look she said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ve just made my peace offerings
    and fulfilled my vows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You’re the one I was looking for!
    I came out to find you, and here you are!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bed is spread with beautiful blankets,
    with colored sheets of Egyptian linen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve perfumed my bed
    with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, let’s drink our fill of love until morning.
    Let’s enjoy each other’s caresses,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for my husband is not home.
    He’s away on a long trip.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has taken a wallet full of money with him
    and won’t return until later this month.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So she seduced him with her pretty speech
    and enticed him with her flattery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He followed her at once,
    like an ox going to the slaughter.
He was like a stag caught in a trap,
speaker: Narrator

text:
awaiting the arrow that would pierce its heart.
He was like a bird flying into a snare,
    little knowing it would cost him his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So listen to me, my sons,
    and pay attention to my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let your hearts stray away toward her.
    Don’t wander down her wayward path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For she has been the ruin of many;
    many men have been her victims.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her house is the road to the grave.
    Her bedroom is the den of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen as Wisdom calls out!
    Hear as understanding raises her voice!
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the hilltop along the road,
    she takes her stand at the crossroads.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the gates at the entrance to the town,
    on the road leading in, she cries aloud,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I call to you, to all of you!
    I raise my voice to all people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You simple people, use good judgment.
    You foolish people, show some understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to me! For I have important things to tell you.
    Everything I say is right,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for I speak the truth
    and detest every kind of deception.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My advice is wholesome.
    There is nothing devious or crooked in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words are plain to anyone with understanding,
    clear to those with knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Choose my instruction rather than silver,
    and knowledge rather than pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wisdom is far more valuable than rubies.
    Nothing you desire can compare with it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I, Wisdom, live together with good judgment.
    I know where to discover knowledge and discernment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All who fear the Lord will hate evil.
    Therefore, I hate pride and arrogance,
    corruption and perverse speech.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Common sense and success belong to me.
    Insight and strength are mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of me, kings reign,
    and rulers make just decrees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rulers lead with my help,
    and nobles make righteous judgments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I love all who love me.
    Those who search will surely find me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have riches and honor,
    as well as enduring wealth and justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My gifts are better than gold, even the purest gold,
    my wages better than sterling silver!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I walk in righteousness,
    in paths of justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who love me inherit wealth.
    I will fill their treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord formed me from the beginning,
    before he created anything else.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was appointed in ages past,
    at the very first, before the earth began.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was born before the oceans were created,
    before the springs bubbled forth their waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the mountains were formed,
    before the hills, I was born—
speaker: Narrator

text:
before he had made the earth and fields
    and the first handfuls of soil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was there when he established the heavens,
    when he drew the horizon on the oceans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was there when he set the clouds above,
    when he established springs deep in the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was there when he set the limits of the seas,
    so they would not spread beyond their boundaries.
And when he marked off the earth’s foundations,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was the architect at his side.
I was his constant delight,
    rejoicing always in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And how happy I was with the world he created;
    how I rejoiced with the human family!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And so, my children, listen to me,
    for all who follow my ways are joyful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to my instruction and be wise.
    Don’t ignore it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joyful are those who listen to me,
    watching for me daily at my gates,
    waiting for me outside my home!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For whoever finds me finds life
    and receives favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But those who miss me injure themselves.
    All who hate me love death.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom has built her house;
    she has carved its seven columns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has prepared a great banquet,
    mixed the wines, and set the table.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has sent her servants to invite everyone to come.
    She calls out from the heights overlooking the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come in with me,” she urges the simple.
    To those who lack good judgment, she says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come, eat my food,
    and drink the wine I have mixed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leave your simple ways behind, and begin to live;
    learn to use good judgment.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who rebukes a mocker will get an insult in return.
    Anyone who corrects the wicked will get hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So don’t bother correcting mockers;
    they will only hate you.
But correct the wise,
    and they will love you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instruct the wise,
    and they will be even wiser.
Teach the righteous,
    and they will learn even more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear of the Lord is the foundation of wisdom.
    Knowledge of the Holy One results in good judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom will multiply your days
    and add years to your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you become wise, you will be the one to benefit.
    If you scorn wisdom, you will be the one to suffer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The woman named Folly is brash.
    She is ignorant and doesn’t know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She sits in her doorway
    on the heights overlooking the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She calls out to men going by
    who are minding their own business.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come in with me,” she urges the simple.
    To those who lack good judgment, she says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Stolen water is refreshing;
    food eaten in secret tastes the best!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But little do they know that the dead are there.
    Her guests are in the depths of the grave.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Tainted wealth has no lasting value,
    but right living can save your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will not let the godly go hungry,
    but he refuses to satisfy the craving of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people are soon poor;
    hard workers get rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise youth harvests in the summer,
    but one who sleeps during harvest is a disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly are showered with blessings;
    the words of the wicked conceal violent intentions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have happy memories of the godly,
    but the name of a wicked person rots away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise are glad to be instructed,
    but babbling fools fall flat on their faces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People with integrity walk safely,
    but those who follow crooked paths will be exposed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People who wink at wrong cause trouble,
    but a bold reproof promotes peace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the godly are a life-giving fountain;
    the words of the wicked conceal violent intentions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hatred stirs up quarrels,
    but love makes up for all offenses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words come from the lips of people with understanding,
    but those lacking sense will be beaten with a rod.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise people treasure knowledge,
    but the babbling of a fool invites disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wealth of the rich is their fortress;
    the poverty of the poor is their destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earnings of the godly enhance their lives,
    but evil people squander their money on sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People who accept discipline are on the pathway to life,
    but those who ignore correction will go astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hiding hatred makes you a liar;
    slandering others makes you a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Too much talk leads to sin.
    Be sensible and keep your mouth shut.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the godly are like sterling silver;
    the heart of a fool is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the godly encourage many,
    but fools are destroyed by their lack of common sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessing of the Lord makes a person rich,
    and he adds no sorrow with it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doing wrong is fun for a fool,
    but living wisely brings pleasure to the sensible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fears of the wicked will be fulfilled;
    the hopes of the godly will be granted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the storms of life come, the wicked are whirled away,
    but the godly have a lasting foundation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people irritate their employers,
    like vinegar to the teeth or smoke in the eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear of the Lord lengthens one’s life,
    but the years of the wicked are cut short.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hopes of the godly result in happiness,
    but the expectations of the wicked come to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the Lord is a stronghold to those with integrity,
    but it destroys the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly will never be disturbed,
    but the wicked will be removed from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouth of the godly person gives wise advice,
    but the tongue that deceives will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lips of the godly speak helpful words,
    but the mouth of the wicked speaks perverse words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests the use of dishonest scales,
    but he delights in accurate weights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pride leads to disgrace,
    but with humility comes wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honesty guides good people;
    dishonesty destroys treacherous people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Riches won’t help on the day of judgment,
    but right living can save you from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly are directed by honesty;
    the wicked fall beneath their load of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godliness of good people rescues them;
    the ambition of treacherous people traps them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked die, their hopes die with them,
    for they rely on their own feeble strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly are rescued from trouble,
    and it falls on the wicked instead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With their words, the godless destroy their friends,
    but knowledge will rescue the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The whole city celebrates when the godly succeed;
    they shout for joy when the wicked die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upright citizens are good for a city and make it prosper,
    but the talk of the wicked tears it apart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is foolish to belittle one’s neighbor;
    a sensible person keeps quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gossip goes around telling secrets,
    but those who are trustworthy can keep a confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without wise leadership, a nation falls;
    there is safety in having many advisers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There’s danger in putting up security for a stranger’s debt;
    it’s safer not to guarantee another person’s debt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gracious woman gains respect,
    but ruthless men gain only wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your kindness will reward you,
    but your cruelty will destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people get rich for the moment,
    but the reward of the godly will last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Godly people find life;
    evil people find death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests people with crooked hearts,
    but he delights in those with integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people will surely be punished,
    but the children of the godly will go free.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A beautiful woman who lacks discretion
    is like a gold ring in a pig’s snout.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly can look forward to a reward,
    while the wicked can expect only judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give freely and become more wealthy;
    be stingy and lose everything.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The generous will prosper;
    those who refresh others will themselves be refreshed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People curse those who hoard their grain,
    but they bless the one who sells in time of need.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you search for good, you will find favor;
    but if you search for evil, it will find you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in your money and down you go!
    But the godly flourish like leaves in spring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who bring trouble on their families inherit the wind.
    The fool will be a servant to the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The seeds of good deeds become a tree of life;
    a wise person wins friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the righteous are rewarded here on earth,
    what will happen to wicked sinners?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To learn, you must love discipline;
    it is stupid to hate correction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord approves of those who are good,
    but he condemns those who plan wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wickedness never brings stability,
    but the godly have deep roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A worthy wife is a crown for her husband,
    but a disgraceful woman is like cancer in his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The plans of the godly are just;
    the advice of the wicked is treacherous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the wicked are like a murderous ambush,
    but the words of the godly save lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked die and disappear,
    but the family of the godly stands firm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A sensible person wins admiration,
    but a warped mind is despised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be an ordinary person with a servant
    than to be self-important but have no food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly care for their animals,
    but the wicked are always cruel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A hard worker has plenty of food,
    but a person who chases fantasies has no sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thieves are jealous of each other’s loot,
    but the godly are well rooted and bear their own fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked are trapped by their own words,
    but the godly escape such trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words bring many benefits,
    and hard work brings rewards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools think their own way is right,
    but the wise listen to others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool is quick-tempered,
    but a wise person stays calm when insulted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An honest witness tells the truth;
    a false witness tells lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people make cutting remarks,
    but the words of the wise bring healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truthful words stand the test of time,
    but lies are soon exposed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deceit fills hearts that are plotting evil;
    joy fills hearts that are planning peace!
speaker: Narrator

text:
No harm comes to the godly,
    but the wicked have their fill of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests lying lips,
    but he delights in those who tell the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise don’t make a show of their knowledge,
    but fools broadcast their foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Work hard and become a leader;
    be lazy and become a slave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Worry weighs a person down;
    an encouraging word cheers a person up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly give good advice to their friends;
    the wicked lead them astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people don’t even cook the game they catch,
    but the diligent make use of everything they find.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the godly leads to life;
    that path does not lead to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise child accepts a parent’s discipline;
    a mocker refuses to listen to correction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words will win you a good meal,
    but treacherous people have an appetite for violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who control their tongue will have a long life;
    opening your mouth can ruin everything.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people want much but get little,
    but those who work hard will prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly hate lies;
    the wicked cause shame and disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Godliness guards the path of the blameless,
    but the evil are misled by sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some who are poor pretend to be rich;
    others who are rich pretend to be poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich can pay a ransom for their lives,
    but the poor won’t even get threatened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The life of the godly is full of light and joy,
    but the light of the wicked will be snuffed out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pride leads to conflict;
    those who take advice are wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth from get-rich-quick schemes quickly disappears;
    wealth from hard work grows over time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hope deferred makes the heart sick,
    but a dream fulfilled is a tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People who despise advice are asking for trouble;
    those who respect a command will succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The instruction of the wise is like a life-giving fountain;
    those who accept it avoid the snares of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person with good sense is respected;
    a treacherous person is headed for destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise people think before they act;
    fools don’t—and even brag about their foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An unreliable messenger stumbles into trouble,
    but a reliable messenger brings healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you ignore criticism, you will end in poverty and disgrace;
    if you accept correction, you will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is pleasant to see dreams come true,
    but fools refuse to turn from evil to attain them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Walk with the wise and become wise;
    associate with fools and get in trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trouble chases sinners,
    while blessings reward the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Good people leave an inheritance to their grandchildren,
    but the sinner’s wealth passes to the godly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor person’s farm may produce much food,
    but injustice sweeps it all away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who spare the rod of discipline hate their children.
    Those who love their children care enough to discipline them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly eat to their hearts’ content,
    but the belly of the wicked goes hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise woman builds her home,
    but a foolish woman tears it down with her own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who follow the right path fear the Lord;
    those who take the wrong path despise him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool’s proud talk becomes a rod that beats him,
    but the words of the wise keep them safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without oxen a stable stays clean,
    but you need a strong ox for a large harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An honest witness does not lie;
    a false witness breathes lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A mocker seeks wisdom and never finds it,
    but knowledge comes easily to those with understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stay away from fools,
    for you won’t find knowledge on their lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The prudent understand where they are going,
    but fools deceive themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools make fun of guilt,
    but the godly acknowledge it and seek reconciliation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each heart knows its own bitterness,
    and no one else can fully share its joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The house of the wicked will be destroyed,
    but the tent of the godly will flourish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a path before each person that seems right,
    but it ends in death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laughter can conceal a heavy heart,
    but when the laughter ends, the grief remains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Backsliders get what they deserve;
    good people receive their reward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Only simpletons believe everything they’re told!
    The prudent carefully consider their steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise are cautious and avoid danger;
    fools plunge ahead with reckless confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Short-tempered people do foolish things,
    and schemers are hated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Simpletons are clothed with foolishness,
    but the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people will bow before good people;
    the wicked will bow at the gates of the godly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor are despised even by their neighbors,
    while the rich have many “friends.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is a sin to belittle one’s neighbor;
    blessed are those who help the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you plan to do evil, you will be lost;
    if you plan to do good, you will receive unfailing love and faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Work brings profit,
    but mere talk leads to poverty!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth is a crown for the wise;
    the effort of fools yields only foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A truthful witness saves lives,
    but a false witness is a traitor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who fear the Lord are secure;
    he will be a refuge for their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear of the Lord is a life-giving fountain;
    it offers escape from the snares of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A growing population is a king’s glory;
    a prince without subjects has nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People with understanding control their anger;
    a hot temper shows great foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A peaceful heart leads to a healthy body;
    jealousy is like cancer in the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who oppress the poor insult their Maker,
    but helping the poor honors him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked are crushed by disaster,
    but the godly have a refuge when they die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is enshrined in an understanding heart;
    wisdom is not found among fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Godliness makes a nation great,
    but sin is a disgrace to any people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king rejoices in wise servants
    but is angry with those who disgrace him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gentle answer deflects anger,
    but harsh words make tempers flare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongue of the wise makes knowledge appealing,
    but the mouth of a fool belches out foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is watching everywhere,
    keeping his eye on both the evil and the good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gentle words are a tree of life;
    a deceitful tongue crushes the spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Only a fool despises a parent’s discipline;
    whoever learns from correction is wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is treasure in the house of the godly,
    but the earnings of the wicked bring trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lips of the wise give good advice;
    the heart of a fool has none to give.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests the sacrifice of the wicked,
    but he delights in the prayers of the upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests the way of the wicked,
    but he loves those who pursue godliness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever abandons the right path will be severely disciplined;
    whoever hates correction will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even Death and Destruction hold no secrets from the Lord.
    How much more does he know the human heart!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mockers hate to be corrected,
    so they stay away from the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A glad heart makes a happy face;
    a broken heart crushes the spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise person is hungry for knowledge,
    while the fool feeds on trash.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the despondent, every day brings trouble;
    for the happy heart, life is a continual feast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to have little, with fear for the Lord,
    than to have great treasure and inner turmoil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bowl of vegetables with someone you love
    is better than steak with someone you hate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A hot-tempered person starts fights;
    a cool-tempered person stops them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy person’s way is blocked with briers,
    but the path of the upright is an open highway.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sensible children bring joy to their father;
    foolish children despise their mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foolishness brings joy to those with no sense;
    a sensible person stays on the right path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Plans go wrong for lack of advice;
    many advisers bring success.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone enjoys a fitting reply;
    it is wonderful to say the right thing at the right time!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The path of life leads upward for the wise;
    they leave the grave behind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord tears down the house of the proud,
    but he protects the property of widows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests evil plans,
    but he delights in pure words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Greed brings grief to the whole family,
    but those who hate bribes will live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart of the godly thinks carefully before speaking;
    the mouth of the wicked overflows with evil words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is far from the wicked,
    but he hears the prayers of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A cheerful look brings joy to the heart;
    good news makes for good health.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you listen to constructive criticism,
    you will be at home among the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you reject discipline, you only harm yourself;
    but if you listen to correction, you grow in understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear of the Lord teaches wisdom;
    humility precedes honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We can make our own plans,
    but the Lord gives the right answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People may be pure in their own eyes,
    but the Lord examines their motives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Commit your actions to the Lord,
    and your plans will succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has made everything for his own purposes,
    even the wicked for a day of disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests the proud;
    they will surely be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unfailing love and faithfulness make atonement for sin.
    By fearing the Lord, people avoid evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When people’s lives please the Lord,
    even their enemies are at peace with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to have little, with godliness,
    than to be rich and dishonest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We can make our plans,
    but the Lord determines our steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king speaks with divine wisdom;
    he must never judge unfairly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord demands accurate scales and balances;
    he sets the standards for fairness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king detests wrongdoing,
    for his rule is built on justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king is pleased with words from righteous lips;
    he loves those who speak honestly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The anger of the king is a deadly threat;
    the wise will try to appease it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the king smiles, there is life;
    his favor refreshes like a spring rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much better to get wisdom than gold,
    and good judgment than silver!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The path of the virtuous leads away from evil;
    whoever follows that path is safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pride goes before destruction,
    and haughtiness before a fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to live humbly with the poor
    than to share plunder with the proud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who listen to instruction will prosper;
    those who trust the Lord will be joyful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise are known for their understanding,
    and pleasant words are persuasive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discretion is a life-giving fountain to those who possess it,
    but discipline is wasted on fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From a wise mind comes wise speech;
    the words of the wise are persuasive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kind words are like honey—
    sweet to the soul and healthy for the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a path before each person that seems right,
    but it ends in death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is good for workers to have an appetite;
    an empty stomach drives them on.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Scoundrels create trouble;
    their words are a destructive blaze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A troublemaker plants seeds of strife;
    gossip separates the best of friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Violent people mislead their companions,
    leading them down a harmful path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With narrowed eyes, people plot evil;
    with a smirk, they plan their mischief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gray hair is a crown of glory;
    it is gained by living a godly life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be patient than powerful;
    better to have self-control than to conquer a city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We may throw the dice,
    but the Lord determines how they fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better a dry crust eaten in peace
    than a house filled with feasting—and conflict.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise servant will rule over the master’s disgraceful son
    and will share the inheritance of the master’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire tests the purity of silver and gold,
    but the Lord tests the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wrongdoers eagerly listen to gossip;
    liars pay close attention to slander.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who mock the poor insult their Maker;
    those who rejoice at the misfortune of others will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grandchildren are the crowning glory of the aged;
    parents are the pride of their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eloquent words are not fitting for a fool;
    even less are lies fitting for a ruler.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bribe is like a lucky charm;
    whoever gives one will prosper!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Love prospers when a fault is forgiven,
    but dwelling on it separates close friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A single rebuke does more for a person of understanding
    than a hundred lashes on the back of a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people are eager for rebellion,
    but they will be severely punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is safer to meet a bear robbed of her cubs
    than to confront a fool caught in foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you repay good with evil,
    evil will never leave your house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Starting a quarrel is like opening a floodgate,
    so stop before a dispute breaks out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Acquitting the guilty and condemning the innocent—
    both are detestable to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is senseless to pay to educate a fool,
    since he has no heart for learning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A friend is always loyal,
    and a brother is born to help in time of need.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s poor judgment to guarantee another person’s debt
    or put up security for a friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who loves to quarrel loves sin;
    anyone who trusts in high walls invites disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crooked heart will not prosper;
    the lying tongue tumbles into trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is painful to be the parent of a fool;
    there is no joy for the father of a rebel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A cheerful heart is good medicine,
    but a broken spirit saps a person’s strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked take secret bribes
    to pervert the course of justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sensible people keep their eyes glued on wisdom,
    but a fool’s eyes wander to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foolish children bring grief to their father
    and bitterness to the one who gave them birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is wrong to punish the godly for being good
    or to flog leaders for being honest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A truly wise person uses few words;
    a person with understanding is even-tempered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even fools are thought wise when they keep silent;
    with their mouths shut, they seem intelligent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unfriendly people care only about themselves;
    they lash out at common sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools have no interest in understanding;
    they only want to air their own opinions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doing wrong leads to disgrace,
    and scandalous behavior brings contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words are like deep waters;
    wisdom flows from the wise like a bubbling brook.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not right to acquit the guilty
    or deny justice to the innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools’ words get them into constant quarrels;
    they are asking for a beating.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouths of fools are their ruin;
    they trap themselves with their lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rumors are dainty morsels
    that sink deep into one’s heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy person is as bad as
    someone who destroys things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The name of the Lord is a strong fortress;
    the godly run to him and are safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich think of their wealth as a strong defense;
    they imagine it to be a high wall of safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Haughtiness goes before destruction;
    humility precedes honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Spouting off before listening to the facts
    is both shameful and foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The human spirit can endure a sick body,
    but who can bear a crushed spirit?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Intelligent people are always ready to learn.
    Their ears are open for knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Giving a gift can open doors;
    it gives access to important people!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first to speak in court sounds right—
    until the cross-examination begins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Flipping a coin can end arguments;
    it settles disputes between powerful opponents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An offended friend is harder to win back than a fortified city.
    Arguments separate friends like a gate locked with bars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words satisfy like a good meal;
    the right words bring satisfaction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongue can bring death or life;
    those who love to talk will reap the consequences.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man who finds a wife finds a treasure,
    and he receives favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor plead for mercy;
    the rich answer with insults.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are “friends” who destroy each other,
    but a real friend sticks closer than a brother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be poor and honest
    than to be dishonest and a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enthusiasm without knowledge is no good;
    haste makes mistakes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People ruin their lives by their own foolishness
    and then are angry at the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth makes many “friends”;
    poverty drives them all away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will not go unpunished,
    nor will a liar escape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek favors from a ruler;
    everyone is the friend of a person who gives gifts!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The relatives of the poor despise them;
    how much more will their friends avoid them!
Though the poor plead with them,
    their friends are gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To acquire wisdom is to love yourself;
    people who cherish understanding will prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will not go unpunished,
    and a liar will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It isn’t right for a fool to live in luxury
    or for a slave to rule over princes!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sensible people control their temper;
    they earn respect by overlooking wrongs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king’s anger is like a lion’s roar,
    but his favor is like dew on the grass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A foolish child is a calamity to a father;
    a quarrelsome wife is as annoying as constant dripping.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fathers can give their sons an inheritance of houses and wealth,
    but only the Lord can give an understanding wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people sleep soundly,
    but idleness leaves them hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep the commandments and keep your life;
    despising them leads to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you help the poor, you are lending to the Lord—
    and he will repay you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discipline your children while there is hope.
    Otherwise you will ruin their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hot-tempered people must pay the penalty.
    If you rescue them once, you will have to do it again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get all the advice and instruction you can,
    so you will be wise the rest of your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You can make many plans,
    but the Lord’s purpose will prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Loyalty makes a person attractive.
    It is better to be poor than dishonest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear of the Lord leads to life,
    bringing security and protection from harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people take food in their hand
    but don’t even lift it to their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you punish a mocker, the simpleminded will learn a lesson;
    if you correct the wise, they will be all the wiser.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Children who mistreat their father or chase away their mother
    are an embarrassment and a public disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you stop listening to instruction, my child,
    you will turn your back on knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A corrupt witness makes a mockery of justice;
    the mouth of the wicked gulps down evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Punishment is made for mockers,
    and the backs of fools are made to be beaten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wine produces mockers; alcohol leads to brawls.
    Those led astray by drink cannot be wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king’s fury is like a lion’s roar;
    to rouse his anger is to risk your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Avoiding a fight is a mark of honor;
    only fools insist on quarreling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those too lazy to plow in the right season
    will have no food at the harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though good advice lies deep within the heart,
    a person with understanding will draw it out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many will say they are loyal friends,
    but who can find one who is truly reliable?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly walk with integrity;
    blessed are their children who follow them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a king sits in judgment, he weighs all the evidence,
    distinguishing the bad from the good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can say, “I have cleansed my heart;
    I am pure and free from sin”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
False weights and unequal measures—
    the Lord detests double standards of every kind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even children are known by the way they act,
    whether their conduct is pure, and whether it is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ears to hear and eyes to see—
    both are gifts from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you love sleep, you will end in poverty.
    Keep your eyes open, and there will be plenty to eat!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The buyer haggles over the price, saying, “It’s worthless,”
    then brags about getting a bargain!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise words are more valuable
    than much gold and many rubies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get security from someone who guarantees a stranger’s debt.
    Get a deposit if he does it for foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stolen bread tastes sweet,
    but it turns to gravel in the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Plans succeed through good counsel;
    don’t go to war without wise advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gossip goes around telling secrets,
    so don’t hang around with chatterers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you insult your father or mother,
    your light will be snuffed out in total darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An inheritance obtained too early in life
    is not a blessing in the end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t say, “I will get even for this wrong.”
    Wait for the Lord to handle the matter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord detests double standards;
    he is not pleased by dishonest scales.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord directs our steps,
    so why try to understand everything along the way?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t trap yourself by making a rash promise to God
    and only later counting the cost.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise king scatters the wicked like wheat,
    then runs his threshing wheel over them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord’s light penetrates the human spirit,
    exposing every hidden motive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unfailing love and faithfulness protect the king;
    his throne is made secure through love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The glory of the young is their strength;
    the gray hair of experience is the splendor of the old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Physical punishment cleanses away evil;
    such discipline purifies the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king’s heart is like a stream of water directed by the Lord;
    he guides it wherever he pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People may be right in their own eyes,
    but the Lord examines their heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is more pleased when we do what is right and just
    than when we offer him sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Haughty eyes, a proud heart,
    and evil actions are all sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Good planning and hard work lead to prosperity,
    but hasty shortcuts lead to poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth created by a lying tongue
    is a vanishing mist and a deadly trap.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The violence of the wicked sweeps them away,
    because they refuse to do what is just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The guilty walk a crooked path;
    the innocent travel a straight road.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to live alone in the corner of an attic
    than with a quarrelsome wife in a lovely home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people desire evil;
    their neighbors get no mercy from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you punish a mocker, the simpleminded become wise;
    if you instruct the wise, they will be all the wiser.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Righteous One knows what is going on in the homes of the wicked;
    he will bring disaster on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who shut their ears to the cries of the poor
    will be ignored in their own time of need.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A secret gift calms anger;
    a bribe under the table pacifies fury.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Justice is a joy to the godly,
    but it terrifies evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person who strays from common sense
    will end up in the company of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who love pleasure become poor;
    those who love wine and luxury will never be rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked are punished in place of the godly,
    and traitors in place of the honest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to live alone in the desert
    than with a quarrelsome, complaining wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise have wealth and luxury,
    but fools spend whatever they get.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever pursues righteousness and unfailing love
    will find life, righteousness, and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise conquer the city of the strong
    and level the fortress in which they trust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Watch your tongue and keep your mouth shut,
    and you will stay out of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mockers are proud and haughty;
    they act with boundless arrogance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Despite their desires, the lazy will come to ruin,
    for their hands refuse to work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people are always greedy for more,
    but the godly love to give!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice of an evil person is detestable,
    especially when it is offered with wrong motives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will be cut off,
    but a credible witness will be allowed to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked bluff their way through,
    but the virtuous think before they act.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No human wisdom or understanding or plan
    can stand against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The horse is prepared for the day of battle,
    but the victory belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Choose a good reputation over great riches;
    being held in high esteem is better than silver or gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich and poor have this in common:
    The Lord made them both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prudent person foresees danger and takes precautions.
    The simpleton goes blindly on and suffers the consequences.
speaker: Narrator

text:
True humility and fear of the Lord
    lead to riches, honor, and long life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Corrupt people walk a thorny, treacherous road;
    whoever values life will avoid it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Direct your children onto the right path,
    and when they are older, they will not leave it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as the rich rule the poor,
    so the borrower is servant to the lender.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who plant injustice will harvest disaster,
    and their reign of terror will come to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are those who are generous,
    because they feed the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Throw out the mocker, and fighting goes, too.
    Quarrels and insults will disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever loves a pure heart and gracious speech
    will have the king as a friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord preserves those with knowledge,
    but he ruins the plans of the treacherous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person claims, “There’s a lion out there!
    If I go outside, I might be killed!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouth of an immoral woman is a dangerous trap;
    those who make the Lord angry will fall into it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A youngster’s heart is filled with foolishness,
    but physical discipline will drive it far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who gets ahead by oppressing the poor
    or by showering gifts on the rich will end in poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to the words of the wise;
    apply your heart to my instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is good to keep these sayings in your heart
    and always ready on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am teaching you today—yes, you—
    so you will trust in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have written thirty sayings for you,
    filled with advice and knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In this way, you may know the truth
    and take an accurate report to those who sent you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t rob the poor just because you can,
    or exploit the needy in court.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord is their defender.
    He will ruin anyone who ruins them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t befriend angry people
    or associate with hot-tempered people,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or you will learn to be like them
    and endanger your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t agree to guarantee another person’s debt
    or put up security for someone else.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you can’t pay it,
    even your bed will be snatched from under you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t cheat your neighbor by moving the ancient boundary markers
    set up by previous generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see any truly competent workers?
    They will serve kings
    rather than working for ordinary people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While dining with a ruler,
    pay attention to what is put before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are a big eater,
    put a knife to your throat;
speaker: Narrator

text:
don’t desire all the delicacies,
    for he might be trying to trick you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t wear yourself out trying to get rich.
    Be wise enough to know when to quit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the blink of an eye wealth disappears,
    for it will sprout wings
    and fly away like an eagle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t eat with people who are stingy;
    don’t desire their delicacies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are always thinking about how much it costs.
    “Eat and drink,” they say, but they don’t mean it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will throw up what little you’ve eaten,
    and your compliments will be wasted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t waste your breath on fools,
    for they will despise the wisest advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t cheat your neighbor by moving the ancient boundary markers;
    don’t take the land of defenseless orphans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For their Redeemer is strong;
    he himself will bring their charges against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Commit yourself to instruction;
    listen carefully to words of knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t fail to discipline your children.
    The rod of punishment won’t kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Physical discipline
    may well save them from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if your heart is wise,
    my own heart will rejoice!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everything in me will celebrate
    when you speak what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t envy sinners,
    but always continue to fear the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be rewarded for this;
    your hope will not be disappointed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, listen and be wise:
    Keep your heart on the right course.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not carouse with drunkards
    or feast with gluttons,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for they are on their way to poverty,
    and too much sleep clothes them in rags.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to your father, who gave you life,
    and don’t despise your mother when she is old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get the truth and never sell it;
    also get wisdom, discipline, and good judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The father of godly children has cause for joy.
    What a pleasure to have children who are wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So give your father and mother joy!
    May she who gave you birth be happy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my son, give me your heart.
    May your eyes take delight in following my ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prostitute is a dangerous trap;
    a promiscuous woman is as dangerous as falling into a narrow well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She hides and waits like a robber,
    eager to make more men unfaithful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has anguish? Who has sorrow?
    Who is always fighting? Who is always complaining?
    Who has unnecessary bruises? Who has bloodshot eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is the one who spends long hours in the taverns,
    trying out new drinks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t gaze at the wine, seeing how red it is,
    how it sparkles in the cup, how smoothly it goes down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For in the end it bites like a poisonous snake;
    it stings like a viper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will see hallucinations,
    and you will say crazy things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will stagger like a sailor tossed at sea,
    clinging to a swaying mast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you will say, “They hit me, but I didn’t feel it.
    I didn’t even know it when they beat me up.
When will I wake up
    so I can look for another drink?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t envy evil people
    or desire their company.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For their hearts plot violence,
    and their words always stir up trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A house is built by wisdom
    and becomes strong through good sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Through knowledge its rooms are filled
    with all sorts of precious riches and valuables.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise are mightier than the strong,
    and those with knowledge grow stronger and stronger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So don’t go to war without wise guidance;
    victory depends on having many advisers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is too lofty for fools.
    Among leaders at the city gate, they have nothing to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who plans evil
    will get a reputation as a troublemaker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The schemes of a fool are sinful;
    everyone detests a mocker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you fail under pressure,
    your strength is too small.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue those who are unjustly sentenced to die;
    save them as they stagger to their death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t excuse yourself by saying, “Look, we didn’t know.”
    For God understands all hearts, and he sees you.
He who guards your soul knows you knew.
    He will repay all people as their actions deserve.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, eat honey, for it is good,
    and the honeycomb is sweet to the taste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the same way, wisdom is sweet to your soul.
    If you find it, you will have a bright future,
    and your hopes will not be cut short.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t wait in ambush at the home of the godly,
    and don’t raid the house where the godly live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly may trip seven times, but they will get up again.
    But one disaster is enough to overthrow the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t rejoice when your enemies fall;
    don’t be happy when they stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord will be displeased with you
    and will turn his anger away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t fret because of evildoers;
    don’t envy the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For evil people have no future;
    the light of the wicked will be snuffed out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, fear the Lord and the king.
Don’t associate with rebels,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for disaster will hit them suddenly.
Who knows what punishment will come
    from the Lord and the king?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Here are some further sayings of the wise:
It is wrong to show favoritism when passing judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A judge who says to the wicked, “You are innocent,”
    will be cursed by many people and denounced by the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it will go well for those who convict the guilty;
    rich blessings will be showered on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An honest answer
    is like a kiss of friendship.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do your planning and prepare your fields
    before building your house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t testify against your neighbors without cause;
    don’t lie about them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And don’t say, “Now I can pay them back for what they’ve done to me!
    I’ll get even with them!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I walked by the field of a lazy person,
    the vineyard of one with no common sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I saw that it was overgrown with nettles.
    It was covered with weeds,
    and its walls were broken down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then, as I looked and thought about it,
    I learned this lesson:
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little extra sleep, a little more slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to rest—
speaker: Narrator

text:
then poverty will pounce on you like a bandit;
    scarcity will attack you like an armed robber.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are more proverbs of Solomon, collected by the advisers of King Hezekiah of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is God’s privilege to conceal things
    and the king’s privilege to discover them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one can comprehend the height of heaven, the depth of the earth,
    or all that goes on in the king’s mind!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remove the impurities from silver,
    and the sterling will be ready for the silversmith.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remove the wicked from the king’s court,
    and his reign will be made secure by justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t demand an audience with the king
    or push for a place among the great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to wait for an invitation to the head table
    than to be sent away in public disgrace.
Just because you’ve seen something,
speaker: Narrator

text:
don’t be in a hurry to go to court.
For what will you do in the end
    if your neighbor deals you a shameful defeat?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When arguing with your neighbor,
    don’t betray another person’s secret.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Others may accuse you of gossip,
    and you will never regain your good reputation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Timely advice is lovely,
    like golden apples in a silver basket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To one who listens, valid criticism
    is like a gold earring or other gold jewelry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trustworthy messengers refresh like snow in summer.
    They revive the spirit of their employer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who promises a gift but doesn’t give it
    is like clouds and wind that bring no rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Patience can persuade a prince,
