    and soft speech can break bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you like honey?
    Don’t eat too much, or it will make you sick!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t visit your neighbors too often,
    or you will wear out your welcome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Telling lies about others
    is as harmful as hitting them with an ax,
wounding them with a sword,
    or shooting them with a sharp arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Putting confidence in an unreliable person in times of trouble
    is like chewing with a broken tooth or walking on a lame foot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Singing cheerful songs to a person with a heavy heart
    is like taking someone’s coat in cold weather
    or pouring vinegar in a wound.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your enemies are hungry, give them food to eat.
    If they are thirsty, give them water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will heap burning coals of shame on their heads,
    and the Lord will reward you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As surely as a north wind brings rain,
    so a gossiping tongue causes anger!
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s better to live alone in the corner of an attic
    than with a quarrelsome wife in a lovely home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Good news from far away
    is like cold water to the thirsty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the godly give in to the wicked,
    it’s like polluting a fountain or muddying a spring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s not good to eat too much honey,
    and it’s not good to seek honors for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person without self-control
    is like a city with broken-down walls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honor is no more associated with fools
    than snow with summer or rain with harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a fluttering sparrow or a darting swallow,
    an undeserved curse will not land on its intended victim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Guide a horse with a whip, a donkey with a bridle,
    and a fool with a rod to his back!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t answer the foolish arguments of fools,
    or you will become as foolish as they are.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be sure to answer the foolish arguments of fools,
    or they will become wise in their own estimation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trusting a fool to convey a message
    is like cutting off one’s feet or drinking poison!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A proverb in the mouth of a fool
    is as useless as a paralyzed leg.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honoring a fool
    is as foolish as tying a stone to a slingshot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A proverb in the mouth of a fool
    is like a thorny branch brandished by a drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An employer who hires a fool or a bystander
    is like an archer who shoots at random.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a dog returns to its vomit,
    so a fool repeats his foolishness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is more hope for fools
    than for people who think they are wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person claims, “There’s a lion on the road!
    Yes, I’m sure there’s a lion out there!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a door swings back and forth on its hinges,
    so the lazy person turns over in bed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people take food in their hand
    but don’t even lift it to their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lazy people consider themselves smarter
    than seven wise counselors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Interfering in someone else’s argument
    is as foolish as yanking a dog’s ears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as damaging
    as a madman shooting a deadly weapon
speaker: Narrator

text:
is someone who lies to a friend
    and then says, “I was only joking.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire goes out without wood,
    and quarrels disappear when gossip stops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A quarrelsome person starts fights
    as easily as hot embers light charcoal or fire lights wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rumors are dainty morsels
    that sink deep into one’s heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Smooth words may hide a wicked heart,
    just as a pretty glaze covers a clay pot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People may cover their hatred with pleasant words,
    but they’re deceiving you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pretend to be kind, but don’t believe them.
    Their hearts are full of many evils.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While their hatred may be concealed by trickery,
    their wrongdoing will be exposed in public.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you set a trap for others,
    you will get caught in it yourself.
If you roll a boulder down on others,
    it will crush you instead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lying tongue hates its victims,
    and flattering words cause ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t brag about tomorrow,
    since you don’t know what the day will bring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let someone else praise you, not your own mouth—
    a stranger, not your own lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stone is heavy and sand is weighty,
    but the resentment caused by a fool is even heavier.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anger is cruel, and wrath is like a flood,
    but jealousy is even more dangerous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An open rebuke
    is better than hidden love!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wounds from a sincere friend
    are better than many kisses from an enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who is full refuses honey,
    but even bitter food tastes sweet to the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who strays from home
    is like a bird that strays from its nest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heartfelt counsel of a friend
    is as sweet as perfume and incense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never abandon a friend—
    either yours or your father’s.
When disaster strikes, you won’t have to ask your brother for assistance.
    It’s better to go to a neighbor than to a brother who lives far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be wise, my child, and make my heart glad.
    Then I will be able to answer my critics.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prudent person foresees danger and takes precautions.
    The simpleton goes blindly on and suffers the consequences.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get security from someone who guarantees a stranger’s debt.
    Get a deposit if he does it for foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A loud and cheerful greeting early in the morning
    will be taken as a curse!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A quarrelsome wife is as annoying
    as constant dripping on a rainy day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stopping her complaints is like trying to stop the wind
    or trying to hold something with greased hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As iron sharpens iron,
    so a friend sharpens a friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As workers who tend a fig tree are allowed to eat the fruit,
    so workers who protect their employer’s interests will be rewarded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a face is reflected in water,
    so the heart reflects the real person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as Death and Destruction are never satisfied,
    so human desire is never satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire tests the purity of silver and gold,
    but a person is tested by being praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You cannot separate fools from their foolishness,
    even though you grind them like grain with mortar and pestle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Know the state of your flocks,
    and put your heart into caring for your herds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for riches don’t last forever,
    and the crown might not be passed to the next generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After the hay is harvested and the new crop appears
    and the mountain grasses are gathered in,
speaker: Narrator

text:
your sheep will provide wool for clothing,
    and your goats will provide the price of a field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you will have enough goats’ milk for yourself,
    your family, and your servant girls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked run away when no one is chasing them,
    but the godly are as bold as lions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When there is moral rot within a nation, its government topples easily.
    But wise and knowledgeable leaders bring stability.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor person who oppresses the poor
    is like a pounding rain that destroys the crops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To reject the law is to praise the wicked;
    to obey the law is to fight them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people don’t understand justice,
    but those who follow the Lord understand completely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be poor and honest
    than to be dishonest and rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Young people who obey the law are wise;
    those with wild friends bring shame to their parents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Income from charging high interest rates
    will end up in the pocket of someone who is kind to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God detests the prayers
    of a person who ignores the law.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who lead good people along an evil path
    will fall into their own trap,
    but the honest will inherit good things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rich people may think they are wise,
    but a poor person with discernment can see right through them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the godly succeed, everyone is glad.
    When the wicked take charge, people go into hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People who conceal their sins will not prosper,
    but if they confess and turn from them, they will receive mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are those who fear to do wrong,
    but the stubborn are headed for serious trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wicked ruler is as dangerous to the poor
    as a roaring lion or an attacking bear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A ruler with no understanding will oppress his people,
    but one who hates corruption will have a long life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A murderer’s tormented conscience will drive him into the grave.
    Don’t protect him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blameless will be rescued from harm,
    but the crooked will be suddenly destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A hard worker has plenty of food,
    but a person who chases fantasies ends up in poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The trustworthy person will get a rich reward,
    but a person who wants quick riches will get into trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Showing partiality is never good,
    yet some will do wrong for a mere piece of bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Greedy people try to get rich quick
    but don’t realize they’re headed for poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the end, people appreciate honest criticism
    far more than flattery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who steals from his father and mother
    and says, “What’s wrong with that?”
    is no better than a murderer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Greed causes fighting;
    trusting the Lord leads to prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who trust their own insight are foolish,
    but anyone who walks in wisdom is safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever gives to the poor will lack nothing,
    but those who close their eyes to poverty will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked take charge, people go into hiding.
    When the wicked meet disaster, the godly flourish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever stubbornly refuses to accept criticism
    will suddenly be destroyed beyond recovery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the godly are in authority, the people rejoice.
    But when the wicked are in power, they groan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father,
    but if he hangs around with prostitutes, his wealth is wasted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A just king gives stability to his nation,
    but one who demands bribes destroys it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To flatter friends
    is to lay a trap for their feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people are trapped by sin,
    but the righteous escape, shouting for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly care about the rights of the poor;
    the wicked don’t care at all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mockers can get a whole town agitated,
    but the wise will calm anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a wise person takes a fool to court,
    there will be ranting and ridicule but no satisfaction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bloodthirsty hate blameless people,
    but the upright seek to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools vent their anger,
    but the wise quietly hold it back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a ruler pays attention to liars,
    all his advisers will be wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor and the oppressor have this in common—
    the Lord gives sight to the eyes of both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a king judges the poor fairly,
    his throne will last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To discipline a child produces wisdom,
    but a mother is disgraced by an undisciplined child.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked are in authority, sin flourishes,
    but the godly will live to see their downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discipline your children, and they will give you peace of mind
    and will make your heart glad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When people do not accept divine guidance, they run wild.
    But whoever obeys the law is joyful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Words alone will not discipline a servant;
    the words may be understood, but they are not heeded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is more hope for a fool
    than for someone who speaks without thinking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A servant pampered from childhood
    will become a rebel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An angry person starts fights;
    a hot-tempered person commits all kinds of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pride ends in humiliation,
    while humility brings honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you assist a thief, you only hurt yourself.
    You are sworn to tell the truth, but you dare not testify.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fearing people is a dangerous trap,
    but trusting the Lord means safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek the ruler’s favor,
    but justice comes from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous despise the unjust;
    the wicked despise the godly.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I am too stupid to be human,
    and I lack common sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have not mastered human wisdom,
    nor do I know the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who but God goes up to heaven and comes back down?
    Who holds the wind in his fists?
Who wraps up the oceans in his cloak?
    Who has created the whole wide world?
What is his name—and his son’s name?
    Tell me if you know!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every word of God proves true.
    He is a shield to all who come to him for protection.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not add to his words,
    or he may rebuke you and expose you as a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, I beg two favors from you;
    let me have them before I die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
First, help me never to tell a lie.
    Second, give me neither poverty nor riches!
    Give me just enough to satisfy my needs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For if I grow rich, I may deny you and say, “Who is the Lord?”
    And if I am too poor, I may steal and thus insult God’s holy name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never slander a worker to the employer,
    or the person will curse you, and you will pay for it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some people curse their father
    and do not thank their mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are pure in their own eyes,
    but they are filthy and unwashed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They look proudly around,
    casting disdainful glances.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have teeth like swords
    and fangs like knives.
They devour the poor from the earth
    and the needy from among humanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The leech has two suckers
    that cry out, “More, more!”
There are three things that are never satisfied—
    no, four that never say, “Enough!”:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the grave,
    the barren womb,
    the thirsty desert,
    the blazing fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that mocks a father
    and despises a mother’s instructions
will be plucked out by ravens of the valley
    and eaten by vultures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are three things that amaze me—
    no, four things that I don’t understand:
speaker: Narrator

text:
how an eagle glides through the sky,
    how a snake slithers on a rock,
    how a ship navigates the ocean,
    how a man loves a woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An adulterous woman consumes a man,
    then wipes her mouth and says, “What’s wrong with that?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are three things that make the earth tremble—
    no, four it cannot endure:
speaker: Narrator

text:
a slave who becomes a king,
    an overbearing fool who prospers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a bitter woman who finally gets a husband,
    a servant girl who supplants her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are four things on earth that are small but unusually wise:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ants—they aren’t strong,
    but they store up food all summer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hyraxes—they aren’t powerful,
    but they make their homes among the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Locusts—they have no king,
    but they march in formation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lizards—they are easy to catch,
    but they are found even in kings’ palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are three things that walk with stately stride—
    no, four that strut about:
speaker: Narrator

text: the lion, king of animals, who won’t turn aside for anything,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the strutting rooster,
    the male goat,
    a king as he leads his army.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have been a fool by being proud or plotting evil,
    cover your mouth in shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the beating of cream yields butter
    and striking the nose causes bleeding,
    so stirring up anger causes quarrels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sayings of King Lemuel contain this message, which his mother taught him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my son, O son of my womb,
    O son of my vows,
speaker: Narrator

text:
do not waste your strength on women,
    on those who ruin kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not for kings, O Lemuel, to guzzle wine.
    Rulers should not crave alcohol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For if they drink, they may forget the law
    and not give justice to the oppressed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Alcohol is for the dying,
    and wine for those in bitter distress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them drink to forget their poverty
    and remember their troubles no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves;
    ensure justice for those being crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, speak up for the poor and helpless,
    and see that they get justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can find a virtuous and capable wife?
    She is more precious than rubies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband can trust her,
    and she will greatly enrich his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She brings him good, not harm,
    all the days of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She finds wool and flax
    and busily spins it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is like a merchant’s ship,
    bringing her food from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She gets up before dawn to prepare breakfast for her household
    and plan the day’s work for her servant girls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She goes to inspect a field and buys it;
    with her earnings she plants a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is energetic and strong,
    a hard worker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes sure her dealings are profitable;
    her lamp burns late into the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her hands are busy spinning thread,
    her fingers twisting fiber.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She extends a helping hand to the poor
    and opens her arms to the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has no fear of winter for her household,
    for everyone has warm clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes her own bedspreads.
    She dresses in fine linen and purple gowns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband is well known at the city gates,
    where he sits with the other civic leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes belted linen garments
    and sashes to sell to the merchants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is clothed with strength and dignity,
    and she laughs without fear of the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When she speaks, her words are wise,
    and she gives instructions with kindness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She carefully watches everything in her household
    and suffers nothing from laziness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her children stand and bless her.
    Her husband praises her:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There are many virtuous and capable women in the world,
    but you surpass them all!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Charm is deceptive, and beauty does not last;
    but a woman who fears the Lord will be greatly praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Reward her for all she has done.
    Let her deeds publicly declare her praise.
speaker: Narrator
